desc.size: Annual or biennial herb, 10 - 30 cm tall, erect to spreading.

part.partText: few or none at flowering, stalked, pinnately divided. Terminal leaflet oblong to broadly triangular.

4 - 10 or more, alternate, stalked, mainly 2 - 4 cm long, pinnately divided into long, thin, similar leaflets (3 - 6 pairs). Terminal leaflet 1 - 3 mm wide, linear to triangular-oblong, margins non-toothed or toothed. Lateral leaflets not much smaller (1 - 3 mm wide), linear to linear- spatula-shaped or narrowly oblong, margins non-toothed.
in a loose, branched cluster, stalked, white, 1 - 4 mm long. Sepals 4, green. Petals 4, longer than sepals. Stamens 6: 4 tall, 2 short.
a narrow pod, erect on an ascending stalk, 2 - 3 cm long.

similarSpecies.comments: Similar to Cardamine pensylvanica but smaller and in drier habitats. The terminal leaflet of C. pensylvanica is broader than the lateral leaflets, and the leaflet base extends down along the leaf axis. The stem leaves of C. hirsuta have a marginal fringe of hairs at the base of their leafstalks.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: A plant typically found in the dry soil of lawns, fields, and open woods; in both shade and sunlight. In the Chicago Region, it has been found growing in ditches, fallow fields (often cornfields), and poorly drained old fields. In a dolomite prairie they were seen occupying the areas containing bare soil and exposed rock.

etymology.comments: Cardamine comes from the Greek word kárdamon, which refers to plants in the cress family. Parviflora is Latin for “small flower.” Arenicola means “growing in sandy places.”
